0.user_question: Sam ran 3 miles on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.  On Tuesday and Thursday, Sam ran 5 miles.  How many miles did Sam run this week?

direct_answer.text:
On Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, Sam ran a total of 3 (Monday) + 3 (Wednesday) + 3 (Friday) = <<3+3+3=9>>9 miles. 
Then we know that on Tuesday and Thursday together, he ran 5 miles plus another 5 miles which equals 5 + 5 =<<5+5=10>>10 miles.
So altogether over these four days, Sam managed to run 9 (from Mon-Fri) + 10 (Tue & Thu)=<<9+10=19>>19 miles during the week. The answer is: 19.

Condition 1 details that Sam runs certain distances on various days:
- Running \( x \) miles on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday (\( x = 3 \) miles each time) means that \(\text{{total}} = x \times 3\) miles for those days. Since \( x = 3 \), this amounts to \( 3 \times 3 = 9 \) miles.
- Additionally, running \( y \) miles on Tuesday and Thursday (\( y = 5 \) miles each time) adds another \( y \times 2 \) miles. With \( y = 5 \), this yields \( 5 \times 2 = 10 \) miles.

Using basic arithmetic operations—addition being our focus here—we combine both results together:
\[ \text{{Total }} = 9 \, \text{{miles}}_{\text{{Mon, Wed, Fri}}} + 10 \, \text{{miles}}_{\text{{Tue, Thu}}} \]
\[ \text{{Combined mileage}} = 9 + 10 = 19 \, \text{{miles}} \]

0.user_question: Sam ran 3 miles on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.  On Tuesday and Thursday, Sam ran 5 miles.  How many miles did Sam run this week?

direct_answer.text:
On Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, Sam ran a total of 3 (Monday) + 3 (Wednesday) + 3 (Friday) = <<3+3+3=9>>9 miles. 
Then we know that on Tuesday and Thursday together, he ran 5 miles plus another 5 miles which equals 5 + 5 =<<5+5=10>>10 miles.
So altogether over these four days, Sam managed to run 9 (from Mon-Fri) + 10 (Tue & Thu)=<<9+10=19>>19 miles during the week. The answer is: 19.
